You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 480]]<|/det|> · Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 571, 495]]<|/det|> · Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 479, 510]]<|/det|> · Do **not** use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 526]]<|/det|> · Do **not** write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 330, 541]]<|/det|> · You may use a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 578, 557]]<|/det|> · You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 590, 215, 601]]<|/det|> # INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 386, 618]]<|/det|> · The total mark for this paper is 40. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 620, 729, 634]]<|/det|> · The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 868, 728, 882]]<|/det|> This document has **16** pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 91, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the forces supporting a metre ruler to determine the weight of the metre ruler.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 819, 136]]<|/det|>
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1. The scale of the metre ruler faces upwards.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 144, 912, 358]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 369, 532, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 401, 146, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 599, 420]]<|/det|>
The student ensures that the metre ruler is horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 831, 451]]<|/det|>
Briefly describe how to check that the ruler is horizontal. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 650, 917, 667]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 680, 146, 698]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 680, 180, 698]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 680, 920, 730]]<|/det|>
The student adjusts distance \(d\) between the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the \(1.50 \text{N}\) load, as shown in Fig. 1.1. He moves the thread supporting the \(1.50 \text{N}\) load so that it is at the mark on the metre ruler shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 737, 680, 902]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 917, 532, 935]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 144, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|> The student moves the \(1.50 \text{N}\) load to distances \(d = 10.0 \text{cm}, 30.0 \text{cm}, 50.0 \text{cm}, 70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). For each distance \(d\), he reads the value \(F_{\mathrm{X}}\) on force meter X. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 457, 136]]<|/det|> His readings are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 149, 541, 166]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 180, 626, 332]]<|/det|>
\(d/\mathrm {cm}\)\(F_{\mathrm {X}}/\mathrm {N}\)
10.01.17
30.01.40
50.01.82
70.02.15
90.02.35
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 344, 853, 363]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(F_{\mathrm {X}}/\mathrm {N}\) (y-axis) against \(d/\mathrm {cm}\) (x-axis). Start the axes at the origin (0, 0). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 384, 393]]<|/det|> Draw a best-fit straight line. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 401, 752, 797]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 798, 920, 816]]<|/det|> [4]

<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 318, 918, 354]]<|/det|>
Briefly explain why resistor \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{p}}\) , shown in Fig. 3.1, must remain in place throughout the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 365, 918, 384]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 479, 88]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the refraction of light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
Refraction is the change in direction of a ray of light when passing into a transparent substance, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 918, 181]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the concentration of a gel affects the angle at which light is refracted when passing from air into the gel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 918, 227]]<|/det|>
A transparent gel block can be made by dissolving gel powder in hot water in a mould and allowing it to cool. Changing the amount of powder will change the concentration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 425, 259]]<|/det|>
Concentration is measured in \(\text{g} /\text{cm}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 398, 291]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 868, 336]]<|/det|>
• samples of gel made at different concentrations and labelled with those concentrations

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 556, 337]]<|/det|>
• a ray-lamp which produces a narrow ray of light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 225, 368]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 457, 399]]<|/det|>
• list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 789, 414]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 485, 428]]<|/det|>
• state the key variable to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 918, 459]]<|/det|>
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 458, 603, 476]]<|/det|>
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
